Setting up dpd_cpp on the HPC


dpd_cpp has been compiled on the HPC in such a way that allows us to use it's executable programs from anywhere within the HPC. It does so by using what are known as runtime libraries, in the form of .so or shared object files. These libraries contain most of the actual code the programs use. And so, certain path variables in your csh environment need to be updated, so it can find the executables, and the .so files they require, whenever you run them.

Instructions for updating your paths as well as compiling dpd_cpp are given below. You can also find a brief description of dpd_cpp's current executable programs which build and process our triblock simulations.

recent.posts

  • 06-02-2015 - Setup dpd_cpp

about.me

Hello World!

My name is Hayden Fuss. I am senior at NC State University, double majoring in Materials Science and Engineering, and Computer Science. If you need to contact me, please email me at whfuss@ncsu.edu.

For the past two years, I've worked as an undergraduate researcher in the Yingling Research Group, where I write post-processing software for Dissipative Particle Dynamics (DPD) simulations. I write the analysis software in C/C++, and use Python and Bash to submit jobs to NCSU's HPC and plot our results.

This past summer, I worked on a team research project at Harvard University where we conducted a big data study of the Boston Marathon bombings using 311 (non-emergency) reports, 911 dispatches, and geocoded tweets from the Boston area. We used existing Python libraries and modules, such as matplotlib and scikit-learn, to plot our data over animated maps of Boston, in order to track how information and sentiment spread throughout the region following the crises.

Lastly, I have fun by trying to program video games. I played with programming games first in Java, and then using SDL in C/C++. Although, I am currently experimenting with Unity and taking CSC 481 this semester.

As far as my strengths go, I am a quick learner, decent at math and physics, and very persistent.
